text.text: Autumn Flavours: 8 Restaurants Keeping it Seasonal

The leaves are a' falling, nights are drawing in and your finger tips are getting a whole lot colder. Thing is you can try and fight it, pursing your lips in anger like a bitter Halloween witch... Or you could embrace the seasons, going out in the world with a smile on your face to frolic in the undergrowth, pick apples, carve pumpkins and forage for mushrooms.

That's what these restaurants have been doing and it seems to be going rather well for them.

tip.text:
If Skittles wanted you to taste the rainbow, then these guys want you to taste the seasons, with menus of foraged bits 'n' bobs (think wild fennel and brambles), wild game and all sorts of other seasonal freshness. The offering is small but trustworthy, starting off with delicate little 'waste snacks' then going into (only slightly bigger) starters and mains.

We tore our way through supple, freshly baked focaccia then cursed our lack of foresight when there was none left to soak up fermented tomato juices. Our wood pigeon was pink, covered in a hazelnut crunch and accented with cherries; pollock was tender as the night and there was no holding back on butter. This is rich, sweet and decadent food which comes dangerous close to being overly fussy but somehow manages not to be.

For charming native flavours, head to this lofty warehouse space in London Bridge; sip on British wine, beer and cider (look out for the apple cider brandy) in amongst delicate foliage; and let the wildness wash over you.

text.text: If Skittles wanted you to taste the rainbow, then these guys want you to taste the seasons, with menus of foraged bits 'n' bobs (think wild fennel and brambles), wild game and all sorts of other seasonal freshness - like these windfall apples being used in an experiment. The offering is small but trustworthy, starting off with delicate little 'waste snacks' then going into (only slightly bigger) starters and mains. And to drink? The apple cider brandy old fashioned - autumn in a glass.

tip.text:
Having been around since '95 (with Trevor Gulliver on wine and Fergus Henderson on food); St John had a cult following long before it bagged itself a Michelin star - and for good reason too. Its simple but excellent menu focused on British classics, quality produce and seasonality has changed the London food scene forever. If we had a sausage roll for every time a restaurant was influenced by St John's nose-to-tail philosophy, we'd be very paunchy indeed.

Meat (and much offal) is handled with unrivalled skill, but so are fishies, veggies, pies, salads and stews - it's proper, homely, all-butter British cooking with no garnishes and not an edible flower in sight. Whether you're in it for the lamb's tongue with cucumber and dill or more of a whole baked fish type - you can be sure the grub will be fire.

text.text: Having been around since '95 (with Trevor Gulliver on wine and Fergus Henderson on food), St John had a cult following long before it bagged itself a Michelin star - and for good reason too. Its simple-but-excellent menu focused on British classics, quality produce and seasonality has changed the London food scene forever. If we had a sausage roll for every time a restaurant was influenced by St John's nose-to-tail philosophy, we'd be very paunchy indeed. Go for seasonal game and hang around for quality vino.

tip.text:
Leroy sits in a genre of restaurant that London certainly isn't short of. The wine is of the natural variety, the bread artisanal and the produce local, seasonal and of the highest quality. But there's something - a little indescribable something - that it does differently. Sure it has a Michelin star, but also it just gets us.

Is it the decor perhaps, which treads the line between smart and stylish so neatly? Or the extensive vinyl collection, neatly slotted above an open kitchen that kicks out palpable sex appeal? Whatever it is, it's a hella convivial place, serving quality European wine, classy bar snacks and some of the tastiest small plates in town. Expect the veggies to be bang on season; offal or seafood to be handled with care; and sauces to ooze the kind of savoury delights that require much sourdough mopping.

text.text: Leroy sits in a genre of restaurant that London certainly isn't short of. The wine is of the natural variety, the bread artisanal and the produce local, seasonal and of the highest quality. Expect the veggies to be bang on season; offal, game or seafood to be handled with care; and sauces to ooze the kind of savoury delights that require much sourdough mopping. Oh and we should probably mention the recent Michelin star...

tip.text:
Head chef Alex Jackson (previously from Dock Kitchen and Rotorino) has described Sardine as home-cooked, southern-European food. You know, the kind of grub your posh, mediterranean grandmother would make - if she frequented the farmer's market and had a penchant for crme frache. That ain't our granny, but we'll happily adopt.

Sardine's menu is especially inspired by the French regions of Provence and Languedoc-Rousillon. The operative word here is "rich" - food comes lovingly bathed in fat and butter. Take the lamb la ficelle, for example: flanked tenderly by white beans and green sauce, this juicy hunk of meat is served with a crusted wall of fat, and we ain't mad at it. The apricot & brown butter tart is in a league of its own, as well. Look out for their monthly themed dinners, which take place on the final Monday of every month and focus on a special dish, ingredient or regional classic.

text.text: Head chef Alex Jackson (previously from Dock Kitchen and Rotorino) has described Sardine as home-cooked, southern-European food. You know, the kind of grub your posh, mediterranean grandmother would make - if she frequented the farmer's market and had a penchant for crme frache. That ain't our granny, but we'll happily adopt. Whatever beauties are in season they'll come lovingly bathed in butter - just how we like it.

tip.text:
Hidden away behind the red brick walls of a converted school - surrounded by a bouncy green lawn, fruit trees and other shrubbery - this restaurant is a pretty magical place: it makes you feel like you're in on a secret. Margot Henderson, the culinary smarts of the operation, cooked in some of the top London restaurants before setting up this little nugget, turning bike sheds into a soothing retreat from the Shoreditch madness. Decor is a thoughtful, modern kind of 'farmhouse chic' with pristine pine furniture and battered straw hats hanging along one wall.

Food - though heavenly - appears similarly effortless: think perfectly seasoned chicken pie, hunks of fuss-free fish and mounds of fresh leaves from the garden. It's the kind of place where lightly stewed plums come with huge sticky-centred meringues and helpings of cream so generous they would have Tom Kerridge in sweats. This is proper nostalgic British cooking - and we bloody love it.

text.text: Hidden away behind the red brick walls of a converted school - surrounded by bouncy green lawn, fruit trees and other shrubbery - this restaurant is a pretty magical place. Margot Henderson, the culinary smarts of the operation, cooked in some of the top London restaurants before setting up this little nugget. Whatever's on the menu you can be sure it'll be the finest produce, freshly caught fish, herbs from the garden and tasty, tasty game.

tip.text:
As if Brixton doesn't have enough goodness in the neighbourhood, it also has one of the best restaurants in the city within its borders - Salon. This overachieving eatery wasn't content with being the favourite of local gastronome types, it also had to go and be named one of the top 40 British restaurants by the Observer. But like any overachiever, they're eager to share their accomplishments in the form of changing seasonal menus with produce sourced from the market.

The vibe: British cuisine influenced by global flavas. You can get a four-course set menu, for 36pp. Which, tbh, is a pretty sweet deal for the kind of scrummy scraps you'll be putting in your mouth. Think Jersey Royals with wild garlic and Devon blue cheese, or rhubarb with whit chocolate, sour cream, and sumac. Flavours. On. Point.

Veggies need not be scared off: the menu is always pretty plant-focused, and the adorable staff is always accommodating. Oh, and if that all wasn't enough for you, they also do brunch.

text.text: Salon is always changing their menus depending on what's yummy and good in the market. This autumn it'll be all sorts of wild mushrooms, crab apples, quince, cavolo nero, pumpkins, chestnuts and more. If you don't know your way around the seasons as well as they do, let the chef choose and order the four-course set menu for 36. Which, tbh, is a pretty sweet deal for the kind of scrummy scraps you'll be putting in your mouth.

tip.text:
As if the Garden Museum wasn't good enough... there's now even more to this restored Lambeth church filled with gardening artefacts. Ok so we hadn't heard of the museum either but now you've got a real good reason to go: the Museum Cafe.

Harry Kaufman (St John Bread & Wine and Lyles) and George Ryle (Padella and Primeur) like to have a little fun with the menu, dishing out changing seasonal dishes full of quality. Sit in amongst the stained glass and bright leafy surrounds and sample something along the lines of aged pork leg with rainbow chard, whole mackerel with samphire and gooseberries or beef tomatoes with boquerones (yummier than anchovies). There's always a reasonably priced and reliably tasty pasta dish on the menu too, proving how well that Italian and British fusion works. We'll see you by the big open windows having our favourite British summertime clich - an Eton mess.

text.text: Chefs Harry and George like to have a little fun with The Garden Cafe menu, dishing out changing seasonal dishes full of quality. Sit in amongst the stained glass and bright leafy surrounds and work you way through autumnal treats like a beetroot and horseradish tarte tatin, or poached pear French toast. There's always a different pasta dish on the menu too, proving how well that Italian and British fusion works.

tip.text:
A private members club and restaurant, Quo Vadis is one of the old boys of seasonal British cooking. With game terrines, wonderfully decadent pies, and a legendary smoked eel sandwich, Chef Patron Jeremy Lee has been cooking traditional British fare since long before it was cool. The grand Soho town house - formerly home to Karl Marx and a brothel (not at the same time) - sets the scene with intricate stained glass and hanging Union Jacks. Inside is just as beautifully archaic with flowers and light giving life to the white tables cloths and antiquated leather banquette seating.

But the food is why youre here. The menu changes monthly and, decorated with hand-drawn illustrations, it looks more like a piece of art. Taking advantage of the seasons we went for wild duck with damson and elderberry; some pork chops, with prunes and almonds; and pumpkin, potato and celeriac gratin. Everything teetered between rich and delicate and you could almost taste the leaves turning and clocks going back (it was late October). We finished with a St Emilion chocolate tart which we still get butterflies thinking about. This is a London institution and feels like a taste of old-money decadence - just be prepared to part with some of your new money for the pleasure.

text.text: A private members club and restaurant, Quo Vadis is one of the old boys of seasonal British cooking. With game terrines, wonderfully decadent pies, and a legendary smoked eel sandwich, Chef Patron Jeremy Lee has been cooking traditional British fare since long before it was cool. Go in autumn and you'll be treated to delights like wild duck with damson and elderberry; some pork chops, with prunes and almonds; and pumpkin, potato and celeriac gratin (in exchange for a fair bit of money of course).
